docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Welcome to the MECH & Cheese Programming Documentation! This guide was created to serve as a complete reference for both FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) and BEST Robotics programming. Whether you're a new member learning the basics or a returning programmer looking to expand your skills, this documentation is designed to guide you step-by-step through everything we do in our codebase and beyond.

Each section is organized by competition, with clear divisions between FRC and BEST content. We’ll begin with foundational programming concepts and progressively move into more advanced, competition-specific material. Along the way, you’ll find links to official resources, tutorials, and citations for everything we reference so you always know where to learn more.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: Our purpose in creating this documentation is simple: to make our team sustainable. By writing everything down and continuously improving our resources, we ensure that future members can pick up where others left off and continue building even greater robots year after year.

docs.title: Goals
docs.text:
Looking ahead, our goals include:

  • Developing our own FRC API to streamline robot programming
  • Expand outreach to help other teams learn from our experiences
  • Building a fully self-sustaining programming pipeline within our team

This documentation is a living project — meant to grow, evolve, and improve with every season.

docs.title: FAQ & Troubleshooting
docs.text: This page provides solutions to common issues encountered when using MKDocs, Material for MKDocs, or collaborating on MECH & Cheese documentation. It is intended to help new members resolve problems quickly without needing to ask for help.

docs.title: 1. Auto-Reload Not Working (mkdocs serve)
docs.text:
Issue: Changes do not appear automatically in the browser when editing Markdown files.

Solution: 1. Stop the server by pressing Ctrl + C in PowerShell. 2. Restart the server:

mkdocs serve

💡 Tip: Always use PowerShell instead of Command Prompt for better compatibility.

docs.title: 2. Broken Links or Images
docs.text:
Issue: Links to other pages or images do not work.

Common Causes & Solutions:

  • Relative paths are incorrect
    • Check the path to the target file or image. For example, if an image is in docs/images/:
~[Diagram](images/example.png)
  • File or folder renamged but links not updated
    • Update all affected links in your Markdown files
  • Spaces or special characters in filenames
    • Use lowercase letters and hgyphens (motor-wiring.png) instead of spaces

docs.title: 3. Git Merge Conflicts
docs.text:
Issue: Conflicts occur when multiple members edit the same file simultaneously

Solution:

1. Pull the latest changes:

git pull origin main

2. Resolve conflicts manually by editing the affected files. 3. Mark conflicts as resolved

git add <file>
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict"

4. Push your changes back to GitHub

💡 Tip: Coordinate with teammates to avoid editing the same files at the same time.

docs.title: 4. Python or pip Issues
docs.text:
Issue: MKDocs or Material fails to install

Solutions:

  • Make sure Python 3.8 or later is installed:
python --version
  • Ensure pip is installed and up-to-date:
python -m ensurepip --upgrade
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
  • Reinstall MKDocs and Material
pip install --upgrade mkdocs mkdocs-material

docs.title: 5. MKDocs Version Issues
docs.text:
Issue: Commands fail because the MKDocs version is outdated

Solution: Check the version:

mkdocs --version

Update if necessary:

pip install --upgrade mkdocs
pip install --upgrade mkdocs-material

docs.title: 6. Fenced Code Blocks Not Rendering Properly
docs.text:
Issue: Code blocks are not displayed correctly on the site

Solutions:

  • Ensure you are using triple backticks (```) to fence the code block
  • Specify the language for syntax highlighting:
```python
print("Hello, MECH & Cheese)
```
  • For nested code blocks, use more backticks for the outer block than the inner block.

docs.title: 7. Preview Issues
docs.text:
Issue: The local preview does not reflect changes.

Solutions:

  1. Stop and restart the server (Ctrl + C → mkdocs serve).
  2. Clear the browser cache or use a private/incognito window.
  3. Make sure you are editing the correct .md file in the project folder.

docs.title: 8. Getting Help
docs.text:
If none of the above solutions work: - Check the MKDocs Documentation - Check the Material for MKDocs Documentation - Ask a MECH & Cheese mentor or team member for guidance.

💡 Tip: Regularly preview, test links, and coordinate changes with teammates to avoid most common issues.

docs.title: Installing MKDocs and Material for MKDocs
docs.text:
Installing MKDocs is a bit different from installing normal applications. Instead of downloading a program or using an app store, MKDocs is installed through the command line using Python's package manager, pip.

Team MECH & Cheese uses MKDocs along with the Material for MKDocs theme to create clean, organized, and professional documentation. This guide walks you through installing everything you need to get started.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before installing MKDocs, make sure the following are installed:

  • Python 3.8 or later
  • pip, which is included with most Python installations

To verify that Python is installed, run:

python --version

or:

python3 --version

If Python is not installed, download it from: https://www.python.org/downloads/

docs.title: Recommended Terminal
docs.text: While MKDocs works in any command-line environment, we strongly recommend using PowerShell instead of Command Prompt. PowerShell handles paths, Python commands, and MKDocs processes more reliably, especially when working with virtual environments or the Material theme.

docs.title: Step 1 — Install MKDocs
docs.text:
Once Python and pip are ready, install MKDocs by running:

pip install mkdocs

To confirm that MKDocs installed correctly:

mkdocs --version

A version number means you're good to go.

docs.title: Step 2 — Install Material for MKDocs
docs.text:
MECH & Cheese uses the Material for MKDocs theme for its clean layout, ease of customization, and powerful features.

Install it using:

pip install mkdocs-material

You can confirm both packages were installed by running:

pip list

Look for:

  • mkdocs
  • mkdocs-material

docs.title: Step 3 — Create a New MKDocs Project
docs.text:
Before creating the project, navigate to the folder where you want your documentation to live. For example, if you want it inside a Documentation folder on your desktop:

cd Desktop/Documentation

Once you are in the correct location, create a new documentation project by running:

mkdocs new my-project

Then move into the project folder:

cd my-project

Inside, you should see:

mkdocs.yml
docs/
  index.md

docs.title: Step 4 — Start the Local Development Server
docs.text:
MKDocs includes a built-in development server that automatically reloads when you save changes. However, Team MECH & Cheese has noticed that auto-reload does not always work consistently on Windows. If your page does not update automatically, don’t worry — this is normal.

Start the server by running:

mkdocs serve

Then visit this address in your browser:

127.0.0.1:8000

docs.title: If auto-reload stops working
docs.text:
Sometimes MKDocs will freeze and stop detecting changes. To fix this:

  1. Go to your PowerShell window
  2. Press Ctrl + C to stop the server
  3. Restart the server with: 
mkdocs serve

This refreshes the build and forces the latest version of the site to appear. You may need to do this frequently while editing.

docs.title: Step 5 — Enable the Material Theme
docs.text:
To switch your site to Material for MKDocs, open the mkdocs.yml file and modify the theme: section as follows:

theme:
  name: material

Save the file and refresh your browser --- your documentation will now use the Material theme.

docs.title: Installation Complete
docs.text:
You now have:

  • MKDocs installed
  • Material for MKDocs enabled
  • A working documentation project
  • A live development server

You are ready to begin building MECH & Cheese's documentation using professional, modern tools.

Recommended next steps include:

  • Setting up a standard project structure
  • Creating navigation and sidebar layouts
  • Learning Markdown formatting basics
  • Customizing the Material theme
  • Writing your first full documentation page

docs.title: Importing from GitHub
docs.text:
This page covers how MECH & Cheese members can import the team documentation from GitHub. If another FRC team wishes to use this documentation as a template, you are welcome to clone or fork the repository and adapt it for your team.

Repository link: https://github.com/Jaegernauts5103/programming-documentation

docs.title: Step 1 — Open PowerShell
docs.text:
We recommend using PowerShell instead of Command Prompt for better compatibility and path handling.

  1. Press Windows + S, type PowerShell, and open it.
  2. Navigate to the folder where you want the documentation to live. For example, to place it in a Documentation folder on your Desktop:
cd Desktop/Documentation

⚠️ If the folder doesn’t exist yet, create it first using:

mkdir Documentation
cd Documentation

docs.title: Step 2 — Clone the Repository
docs.text:
Use git clone to download the repository locally:

git clone https://github.com/Jaegernauts5103/programming-documentation.git

This will create a new folder named programming-documentation inside your current directory.

docs.title: Step 3 — Navigate into the Project
docs.text:
Move into the cloned directory:

cd programming-documentation

You should now see the following structure:

mkdocs.yml
docs/
  index.md
  // all documentation pages and folders

mkdocs.yml docs/ index.md

docs.title: Step 4 — Install Dependencies (if not already done)
docs.text:
Ensure that MKDocs and the Material theme are installed as per the installation guide. If you skipped the MKDocs installation, but completed the rest of the installation steps, run:

pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

docs.title: Step 5 — Preview the Documentation
docs.text:
Start the MKDocs development server to preview the site locally:

mkdocs serve

Open a browser and go to:

http://127.0.0.1:8000

... or you can simply Ctrl + Left Click the link provided in PowerShell (given you are using PowerShell).

⚠️ If changes don't appear automatically due to auto-reload issues:

  1. Go to PowerShell and press Ctrl + C to stop the server
  2. Restart it with mkdocs serve

docs.title: Step 6 — Update Your Local Copy
docs.text:
To get the latest updates from the GitHub repository in the future:

git pull origin main

This will fetch and merge changes made in the repository.

Another option, if you are using and are familiar with VSCode, you can navigate to the Source Control section in the navigation bar located on either the left or right side of your screen and push, pull, and fetch changes from there.

docs.title: Step 7 — Customizing for Your Team
docs.text:
If you are another FRC team using this as a template:

  • Rename the project folder if desired.
  • Edit mkdocs.yml to adjust navigation, theme settings, or project name
  • Replace content in the docs/ folder with your own documentation
  • Keep the structure in tact for smooth operation with MKDocs and the Material theme

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Use PowerShell for these steps on Windows (not required, but HIGHLY recommended)
  • Regularly pull changes to stay up to date if collaborating with other MECH & Cheese members
  • This step ensures a professional, organized documentation workflow for your team

docs.title: Markdown Formatting & Best Practices
docs.text:
This page provides guidelines and examples for writing clean, consistent Markdown documentation for MECH & Cheese. Following these practices ensures readability, maintainability, and a professional appearance on your MKDocs site.

Each guideline includes the recommended code along with a preview of how it will appear on the site, when applicable.

docs.title: 1. Headings
docs.text:
Use headings to organize content hierarchically:

# Main Title (H1)
## Section Title (H2)
### Subsection Title (H3)
#### Optional Sub-subsection (H4)
  • Only one # per page for the main title.
  • Use headings consistently to structure content clearly.

docs.title: 2. Text Formatting
docs.text:
• Bold important terms: PID Loop → PID Loop **this bolds text!**
  • Italicize emphasis: important note → important note *this italicizes text!*
  • Combine bold and italics: very important → very important ***this bolds and italicizes text!***

docs.title: 3. Lists
docs.text:
Unordered Lists

* First item
* Second item
  * Sub-item
* Third item
  • First item
  • Second item
  • Sub-item
  • Third item

Ordered Lists

1. Step one
2. Step two
   1. Sub-step
3. Step three
  1. Step one
  2. Step two
  3. Sub-step
  4. Step three

docs.title: 4. Links
docs.text:
Internal Links (within the documentation)

[Chassis Overview](chassis/overview.md)

External Links

[MECH & Cheese GitHub](https://github.com/Jaegernauts5103/programming-documentation)

Linking to Headings

[Motor Wiring](chassis/wiring.md#wiring-the-motors)

docs.title: 5. Code Blocks
docs.text:
Inline Code

Use backticks for inline code: Use `git clone` to copy the repo

Fenced Code Blocks

```bash
This is a fenced code block!
It can span as many lines as I want.

It can have gaps between lines.
It can also have no gap between lines
```
  • Always use fenced code blocks with triple backticks.
  • Include the language (bash, python, etc.) for syntax highlighting.
  • With Material theme, a copy button can appear automatically on fenced code blocks.

docs.title: 6. Tables
docs.text:
| Component       | Description           | Notes               |
|-----------------|-------------------|-------------------|
| Neo Motor       | Drive motor        | 400 RPM max       |
| Encoder         | Measures position  | Absolute, Rev     |
Component Description Notes Neo Motor Drive motor 400 RPM max Encoder Measures position Absolute, Rev

docs.title: 7. Images
docs.text:
• Place images in an images/ folder.
  • Link using relative paths:
![Motor Wiring Diagram](images/motor-wiring.png)
  • Add descriptive alt text for clarity.

docs.title: 8. Blockquotes
docs.text:
Use for notes, warnings, or tips

> ⚠️ Always disconnect power before working on wiring.
>
> Tip: Use a consistent color scheme for diagrams.

This is a blockquote.

It can span multiple lines.

docs.title: 9. Tips for Clean Documentation
docs.text:
• Keep sentences short and clear
  • Break large sections into multiple pages if needed
  • Preview regularly with mkdocs serve
  • Use consistent terminology for subsystems, commands, and hardware
  • Update links whenever pages are moved or renamed

docs.title: 10. Summary
docs.text:
• Following these Markdown formatting rules ensures that MECH & Cheese documentation is:
  • Professional and readable
  • Easy to navigate and maintain
  • Ready for new members to contribute quickly
  • Fully compatible with MKDocs and Material theme features, including code copy buttons and syntax highlighting

docs.title: Customizing the Material Theme
docs.text: This page explains how to customize the Material for MKDocs theme used in MECH & Cheese documentation. By following these guidelines, you can adjust the appearance, layout, and features to match our team branding and improve usability.

docs.title: 1. Changing the Theme Colors
docs.text:
Material allows you to define primary and accent colors in mkdocs.yml:

theme:
  name: material
  palette:
    primary: 'deep orange'
    accent: 'orange'
  • You can use Material color names or hex codes.
  • Recommended for MECH & Cheese: primary: #4051B5 (team color), accent: #4051B5 (can be changed).

docs.title: 2. Adding a Logo
docs.text:
You can display the team logo in the header:

theme:
  name: material
  logo: images/mech_cheese_logo.png
  • Place the image in your docs/images/ folder
  • Recommended size: ~40-80px height for header

docs.title: 3 Configuring the Navigation
docs.text:
The sidebar and top navigation can be customized in mkdocs.yml:

nav:
  - Overview: index.md
  - Getting Started: getting-started.md
  - Chassis:
      - Overview: chassis/overview.md
      - Wiring: chassis/wiring.md

Tips: * Use folders for topics to keep the sidebar organized * Use descriptive names to help new members quickly find information

docs.title: 4. Enabling Search
docs.text:
Material includes a built-in search bar. To enable:

theme:
  name: material
  features:
    - search.highlight
    - search.suggest
  • search.highlight highlights matching terms
  • search.suggest provides suggestions while typing

docs.title: 5. Enabling Code Copy Buttons
docs.text:
Make all fenced code blocks easier to copy:

theme:
  name: material
  features:
    - content.code.copy
  • Adds a small copy icon to the top-right of each code block
  • Works automatically on fenced code blocks with language specified:
git clone https://github.com/Jaegernauts5103/programming-documentation.git

docs.title: 6. Using Tabs and Collapsible Sections
docs.text:
Material supports advanced formatting like tabs and collapsible sections for better organization:

Tabs Example:

=== "Python"

    ```python
    print("Hello, world!")
    ```

=== "Java"

    ```java
    System.out.println("Hello, world!");
    ```

Collapsible Section Example:

??? note "Important Note"
    Always disconnect power before working on wiring.

docs.title: 7. Custom Fonts and Icons
docs.text:
You can customize fonts and icons in mkdocs.yml using extra:

extra:
  font:
    text: "Roboto"
    code: "Fira Code"
  • text: font for body text
  • code: font for code blocks
  • Icons can be adding using Material icon syntax in Markdown

docs.title: 8. Summary
docs.text:
Customizing Material for MKDocs allows MECH & Cheese documentation to:

  • Match team branding
  • Improve navigation and readability
  • Enhance usability for new members
  • Include professional styling with minimal effort

💡 Tip: Always preview changes locally using mkdocs serve before committing to GitHub.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
In November 2025, Team 5103 adopted MKDocs as our primary documentation platform. We chose MKDocs because it simplifies the writing process, reduces the intimidation often associated with documentation, and provides a streamlined, organized workflow for the entire team.

This section of our documentation is designed to:

  • Teach current and future members how to use MKDocs effectively
  • Establish long-term, maintainable documentation practices
  • Preserve the team’s knowledge base from season to season
  • Support other FRC teams interested in transitioning to MKDocs

Whether you're brand new to documentation or refining your workflow, this guide will walk you through everything you need to know.

docs.title: What This Documentation Covers
docs.text: This MKDocs section will guide you through the major concepts, tools, and workflows needed to build professional, organized, and maintainable documentation. Topics include:

docs.title: 1. Getting Started
docs.text:
• What MKDocs is and how it works
  • Installing MKDocs and required dependencies
  • Understanding the folder structure (docs/, mkdocs.yml, etc.)

docs.title: 2. Writing Documentation
docs.text:
• Creating pages using Markdown
  • Formatting text, images, links, lists, and code blocks
  • Best practices for clarity and consistency

docs.title: 3. Site Structure & Navigation
docs.text:
• Editing the sidebar (nav: in mkdocs.yml)
  • Organizing pages into sections
  • Naming conventions and file placement

docs.title: 4. Themes & Styling
docs.text:
• Using the Material for MKDocs theme
  • Customizing colors, fonts, icons, and features
  • Adding tabs, callouts, code blocks, and other UI enhancements

docs.title: 5. Extensions
docs.text:
• Useful Markdown and Material extensions
  • How to enable and configure them
  • Examples of common extensions (admonitions, emojis, search, etc.)

docs.title: 6. Version Control & Deployment
docs.text:
• Using Git to store documentation
  • Branching strategies for docs
  • Deploying with GitHub Pages or another hosting provider
  • Automating builds and deployments

docs.title: 7. Team Workflow
docs.text:
• How Team 5103 organizes its documentation
  • Contributing guidelines for new members
  • Review and approval process for edits
  • Tips to make documentation a natural part of robot development

docs.title: Final Notes
docs.text:
Our goal is to ensure that every member—new or returning—can confidently contribute to high-quality documentation. By standardizing our process and sharing what we've learned, we hope to strengthen our team’s knowledge base and support other FRC teams looking to enhance their documentation practices.

If you're ready to begin, head to the Getting Started section!

docs.title: Project Structure & Best Practices
docs.text: This page explains the recommended project structure for MECH & Cheese’s MKDocs documentation and provides best practices for writing and organizing content. Following these guidelines will make your documentation professional, maintainable, and easy for new members to contribute to.

docs.title: 1. Recommended Folder Structure
docs.text:
Organizing your files consistently prevents confusion as the documentation grows.

programming-documentation/
├─ mkdocs.yml
├─ docs/
│ ├─ index.md # Overview page
│ ├─ getting-started.md
│ ├─ chassis/
│ │ ├─ overview.md
│ │ ├─ wiring.md
│ │ └─ maintenance.md
│ ├─ programming/
│ │ ├─ overview.md
│ │ ├─ subsystems.md
│ │ └─ commands.md
│ ├─ sensors/
│ │ └─ overview.md
│ └─ reference/
│ └─ glossary.md

Notes:

  • Each main topic gets its own folder inside of the docs folder (chassis/, programming/, sensors/)
  • Each folder can have multiple Markdown pages for specific topics
  • index.md serves as the landing page for the documentation
  • Keep file names lowercase and hyphenated for consistency

docs.title: 2. Navigation & Sidebar
docs.text:
The sidebar is defined in mkdocs.yml. Example:

nav:
  - Overview: index.md
  - Getting Started: getting-started.md
  - Chassis:
      - Overview: chassis/overview.md
      - Wiring: chassis/wiring.md
      - Maintenance: chassis/maintenance.md
  - Programming:
      - Overview: programming/overview.md
      - Subsystems: programming/subsystems.md
      - Commands: programming/commands.md
  - Sensors:
      - Overview: sensors/overview.md
  - Reference:
      - Glossary: reference/glossary.md

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Order pages logically, top-level topics first
  • Use folders for subtopics rather than long page names
  • Update the sidebar whenever new pages are added

docs.title: Markdown File Naming
docs.text:
• Use lowercase letters
  • Use hyphens to separate words (robot-setup.md)
  • Keep names short but descriptive

docs.title: 4. Writing Guidelines
docs.text:
• Use headings consistently (# for main titles, ## for sections, ### for sub-sections)
  • Use fenced code blocks for commands:
git clone https://github.com/Jaegernauts5103/programming-documentation.git
  • Use bold for important terms (PID loop)
  • Use links to other pages:
[Chassis Overview](chassis/overview.md)
  • Use lists for instructions:
1. Install dependencies
2. Clone the repository
3. Run mkdocs serve
  • Add images for diagrams, wiring, and examples:
![Motor Wiring Diagram](images/motor-wiring.png)

docs.title: 5. Best Practices for Collaboration
docs.text:
• Always preview locally with mkdocs serve before committing
  • Pull changes regularly: git pull origin main
  • Write clear commit messages for documentation updates
  • Use the established folder structure when adding new content

docs.title: 6. Summary
docs.text:
Following this structure and these practices ensures that:

  • Documentation stays organized and navigable
  • New members can quickly find relevant information
  • Updates are easy to track and merge
  • Your MKDocs site remains professional and readable

Tip: Before adding a new page, ask yourself:

  • Does it fit under an existing folder, or does it need a new topic folder?
  • Is the page name clear and descriptive?
  • Will it be easy to link from the sidebar or other pages?

docs.title: Writing Guidelines & Documentation Workflow
docs.text: This page provides best practices for writing and maintaining MECH & Cheese documentation. Following these guidelines ensures that all team members can contribute efficiently, and that documentation remains consistent and professional over time.

docs.title: 1. General Writing Guidelines
docs.text:
• Be clear and concise: Use short sentences and simple language.
  • Use consistent terminology: Refer to subsystems, commands, and hardware using agreed-upon names.
  • Use proper Markdown formatting: Headings, lists, code blocks, and links should follow the standards outlined in the Markdown

Formatting page.

  • Add examples when helpful: Show code snippets, wiring diagrams, or screenshots to illustrate instructions.
  • Use relative links: Always link to other pages or images using relative paths to avoid broken links.

docs.title: 2. Page Organization
docs.text:
• Start with a main heading (#) for the page title.
  • Break content into logical sections using ## or ### headings.
  • Use lists, tables, and code blocks to make content easy to scan.
  • Include a summary or key points section at the end of longer pages.

docs.title: 1. Preview Locally
docs.text:
• Run mkdocs serve to preview changes before committing.
  • Make sure formatting, links, and code blocks render correctly.

docs.title: 2. Create a Branch (Optional but Recommended)
docs.text:
git checkout -b my-feature-branch
  • Useful if multiple people are working on the documentation simultaneously

docs.title: 3. Make Your Changes
docs.text:
• Add or edit Markdown files in the appropriate folder
  • Follow folder structure and naming conventions

docs.title: 4. Commit Changes with Clear Messages
docs.text:
git add .
git commit -m "Add wiring instructions for drive motors"

docs.title: 5. Pull Latest Changes Before Pushing
docs.text: git pull origin main

docs.title: 6. Push Changes to GitHub
docs.text: git push origin my-feature-branch

docs.title: 7. Merge or Create Pull Requests
docs.text:
• Use GitHub to merge your branch into main
  • Review by another team member if possible to catch errors

docs.title: 4. Collaboration Best Practices
docs.text:
• Communicate with your team about which pages you’re editing.
  • Avoid editing the same file simultaneously without coordination.
  • Regularly pull changes from the main branch to avoid merge conflicts.
  • Maintain consistent formatting across all pages (headings, lists, code blocks).

docs.title: 5. Updating Existing Pages
docs.text:
• Check the page for outdated information before making edits
  • Preserve existing examples and formatting where possible
  • Add a "last updated" note at the top or bottom if necessary:
*Last updated: November 2025*

docs.title: 6. Summary
docs.text:
Following these writing guidelines and workflow steps ensures that MECH & Cheese documentation is:

  • Professional and consistent
  • Easy for new members to read and understand
  • Easy to maintain and update over multiple seasons
  • Collaborative, minimizing conflicts between team members

💡 Tip: Always preview your changes locally with mkdocs serve and check links and code blocks before pushing to GitHub.
